awd_titl_txt: Theory of the Speed-Limited Particle-in-Cell Simulation Method
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will develop the theory and explore practical applications of a new algorithm for simulation of plasma -- a state of matter with freely interacting electrons and ions not bound together in atoms.  This new algorithm has the potential to enable simulation of larger and more complicated plasma systems, leading to a better fundamental understanding of plasma physics, improved predictive capabilities for space weather, better modeling of fusion devices and plasma-based rocket thrusters, and more efficient manipulation of plasma for semiconductor fabrication and other industrial purposes.

The new algorithm, the speed-limited particle-in-cell (SLPIC) method, is an extreme variant of the immensely useful particle-in-cell (PIC) technique.  SLPIC facilitates multiscale simulation by avoiding the need to resolve unimportant small-scale phenomena -- phenomena that must otherwise often be resolved, even when physically negligible, to avoid numerical instabilities.  To accomplish this, SLPIC limits the speed of fast particles (e.g., electrons), while keeping track of what their actual speed should be.  The speed-limited motion is a consequence of an approximate Vlasov equation; it accurately simulates particle distribution functions as long as they change sufficiently slowly.  This project will develop the theory and use of SLPIC, examining its advantages and disadvantages with respect to standard PIC simulation, and apply it to test problems, including plasma sheaths, the solar wind, and Hall rocket thrusters.  In addition, this project will explore the possibility that SLPIC techniques might help mitigate the finite grid instability well-known in standard PIC methods.

por.por_cntn:
The particle-in-cell (PIC) simulation method is widely-used to study and understand plasma behavior from first principles.  The Speed-Limited PIC (SLPIC) method was developed by this project to allow faster PIC simulation in certain scenarios, while still representing the plasma as charged particles.  In particular, the large mass ratio between ions and electron often makes PIC prohibitively expensive because electrons are so much faster than ions, and SLPIC alleviates this problem.  The tradeoff for using SLPIC is that fast phenomena (such as electron plasma oscillations) are not accurately simulated.  Over the course of this project, we developed the theory of Speed-Limited plasmas and showed that, as hoped, fast phenomena are slowed unphysically (thereby preventing numerical instability), but that slow phenomena (such as ion acoustic waves) are accurately simulated.  Importantly, SLPIC requires only relatively minor modifications of the basic PIC algorithm.  Thus we implemented SLPIC within an already-existing PIC code, and demonstrated its usefulness in three scenarios: simulating plasma sheaths, Langmuir probes, and Paschen's law (the latter showed how SLPIC worked seamlessly with the existing PIC Monte Carlo Collision algorithm).  In these cases, we verified that SLPIC yielded the same results as standard PIC, with more than an order of magnitude less computation.  In addition, we showed how SLPIC relates to a fundamental scaling of the Vlasov-Poisson system (describing electrostatic plasma behavior); and we outlined an approach for applying SLPIC to magnetized plasmas.

This project has trained a graduate student, who is the first author on one of papers we published on SLPIC. In addition, the success of this project has led to another project to use SLPIC (among other techniques) to optimize magnetron sputtering, which is widely used in industry for thin film coating (for example, for semiconductor fabrication).
